results.adx_keywords: World Cup 2014 (Soccer);Brazil;Croatia;Soccer;Neymar
results.title: Player Tumbles; Opposition Falls
results.abstract: Brazil, the host country and favorite for the World Cup, was awarded a penalty kick despite Croatia’s protests, leading to the decisive goal in the tournament opener.

media.caption: The referee Yuichi Nishimura, bottom left, awarded a penalty kick to Brazil when Fred fell to the ground after making light contact with a Croatian player.

Marcelo, right, had the tournament’s first goal — but for the wrong team. A retreating Marcelo essentially ran the ball into the net in the 11th minute for Brazil’s first own goal in World Cup history.
Neymar had two goals for Brazil, the second on a penalty kick in the 71st minute.

results.title: World Cup Opinions in 19 Countries: Likes, Dislikes, Predictions
results.abstract: Argentina, the United States and Iran appear to be the most disliked World Cup teams. Brazilian supporters enter the tournament as the most confident fans.

results.byline: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and STEVEN YACCINO
results.title: Efforts by Colleges to Curb Assaults Focus on Fraternities
results.abstract: As colleges come under intense pressure to curb sexual assault, binge drinking and hazing, they are increasingly looking at their fraternities.

media.caption: Josiah Terrell-Perica, a junior at Amherst College in western Massachusetts, helps clean an off-campus house where members of the Chi Psi fraternity live. Amherst, which has long barred such housing on its campus, will from July 1 prohibit students from belonging to any fraternity or sorority.
